JOANNE RUDOF: This is February 17th, 1994 at the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust testimonies, Yale University. I am Joanne Rudoff.
FRANCES COHEN: And I'm Frances Cohen.

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: And my name is Sydney Bruskin. I was born at May 17th, 1914 in Ansonia, Connecticut. My parents were immigrants. They came from Russia. And when I was four years old, we moved to New Haven. I was educated here. I went to Hill House High School, class of 1932. And then I went to Yale, the class of 1936. I majored in French, and I also always liked languages, so I took a couple of years of German and two years of Italian.

And I, um-- personally, I just briefly say that like, Depression time, that I was qualified to be a teacher. I had a certificate, but I couldn't get a job. And through some strange circumstance, I wound up in the bicycle business, even though I did not know how to ride a bicycle.
[CHUCKLING]

Well, um, then, um, I was married and-- a--on August 8th, 1941. And our daughter, Phyllis, was born on May 30th, 1943. Most of my friends were not married. They were drafted. Um, I was not drafted right away. I guess when they got to the bottom of the barrel or something, then they figured they needed guys like me, who were, eh-- you know, we were married and had a child.

So, um, there was a problem, though, because I didn't want to give up my bicycle business. And uh, we-- we were having problems hiring mechanics to work for us. Because as fast as we hired them, they'd be drafted too. Finally, we located one gentleman who weighed 250 pounds. He was overweight. So he stayed with us for a while. But eventually, they took him also. But anyhow, my wife kept the business going while I was in the service.

Um, I-- I got my, uh, letter from the president in September of 1943. And then in October, I was inducted uh, uh, at the-- at the armory on Orange Street here in New Haven. And I went along with a lot of other, uh, young men, uh, to er, Fort Devens in Massachusetts. I remember it was, um-- I-- I was not too reluctant to go. I was full of adventure then. I knew I'd have to go.

And so for, of course, I-- I remember I was very sad, because my daughter was just a few months old. And I'll never forget, it was the-- the only time I ever saw my father cry-- and I was shocked-- was at the railroad station when he saw me off, along with Mayor Murphy there. A--a-- and-- and I just couldn't fathom it, as if to say he-- maybe he won't come back.

Well, anyhow, Devens-- from Devens, um, one day, we-- we just had to sit around and wait, do nothing, close order drill and so forth. And then they said, OK, men, we're moving out tomorrow morning, and, um, leave your heavy clothing on top of your duffel bag, overcoats and so forth, and, uh, uh, heavy underwear and all that. So we figured we were probably going to a place like Alaska or something. Well, the Army of course, was vice versa. They sent us to Mississippi, down south.

So, eh, eh, we-- we went to, uh, Camp Shelby, Hattiesburg, Mississippi. And I was put in the 65th infantry division, uh, 261st regiment, the headquarters company. And there, um, we had the, uh, usual, the basic training and so forth, uh, which I survived. It was pretty rugged, but I managed.

And um-- and then all of a sudden, one day, you know-- I'd only been here just a few months, and they said that they-- they're desperate, they need troops overseas. So they were ta-- taking, uh, all the, um, privates and PFCs, private first class. And I was a PFC at that poi-- point. And they were taking us, so they shipped us up to Fort Meade.

And there-- as soon as we got there, be-- before we had a chance to do anything, they told us to report to the artillery range to fire a hand grenade. It seems that it-- with all the training that we had in Mississippi, we had not, uh, used-- throwing a hand grenade. So we had to make sure to do it. Because they had some disastrous results with some of the soldiers who had never thrown before.

So I remember throwing the grenade. It was a little scary, but I made it. And then we sailed to England. Uh, I don't remember the name of the ship. It was a tremendous ship. Uh, it, um-- it took us only six days, whereas--
JOANNE RUDOF: When was that?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: That-- that was in, um, March of 194-- eh, 44, March of '44. And, uh, then I remember the-- the boat landed at Liverpool. And then we went to a little town, a quaint English town called Market Drayton. And we were there for several weeks. I remember sleeping in a Quonset hut, which was very uncomfortable. Uh, it-- it was-- it was cold then, and, uh, there was just a little, uh, wood fire in the hut, maybe 50 GI's sleeping there, and-- and-- and then, um-- th-- then, um.

I remember one little incident where I didn't know how long I was going to stay there. One of the things you're doing is pulling guard duty. And one morning, I was pulling guard duty, and a young English boy came along-- about nine or 10 years-- riding a bicycle, a Raleigh bicycle. I said, gee. I said, I'd like to buy that bicycle. He said, OK.

I said it. So I made an appointment with him. The next morning, I was going to give him I don't know how many pounds-- a few pounds-- to get the bicycle. Well, eh, eh, my plans were changed, because we-- they said we're going to France instead. So that took care of that.

So anyhow, we-- we crossed the Channel, landed at Omaha Beach. I figured it was about D-day plus 30. Omaha Beach was clean then. We'd heard the stories of all the-- the-- the-- the corpses of the American soldiers on the beach and all that, but it was perfectly clean, I remember. And, uh, it was peaceful there too.

And then f-- f-- then we-- they trucked us a few miles away to what we-- I was not assigned to any outfit at that point. I was a replacement, eh, we-- we called it a repo depot, a replacement depot. And, uh, I remember s-- staying in a, um-- a-- in a little pup tent with another guy, um, eh, Holmes, his name was. He's from Philadelphia. And we stayed there. And then one day, I was told to report, um-- no, I know-- that somebody would pick me up and I was going to be assigned to the 80th infantry division Counterintelligence Corps, CIC.

And, uh, that was in France. And I remember the first place, we went to Dieulouard in-- in, um-- in, uh-- in--in France, which is near Nancy. And, uh, there, I had no briefing on what I was supposed to do, but I knew I was picked because of my la-- knowledge of languages. And, um, then-- th-- then I was assign-- the-- the-- the CIC unit comprised maybe 25 men. They were divided into three or four different groups. And I was wi-- with a group of about four or five men. Uh, Tom Eddington was the uh, sergeant in charge of our group.

Incidentally, in the CIC, we never wore our-- our grade. Whether you're a colonel or a private or a sergeant, we were all known as agents. We had US here, and CIC, but that's all. Because this way, when we interrogated somebody, we didn't-- if we interrogated a high mucka muck f-- uh, Nazi, we-- we didn't want him to feel that I was a lowly private or a private first class, so we were all agents.

Well, there wasn't much to do for us in France. Uh, w-- let's see, counter-intelligence was supposed to be protect the security of our troops. At first, that was it. In other words, uh, we were supposed to find out if there are any uh, Nazi collaborators amongst the French people. We had w-- uh-- we had a very-- a couple of very good informants for us, uh, from the FFI, the free French. Uh, we had one-- one gentleman who-- who was-- was underground during most of the war. And he--he pointed out some of the Nazi collaborators, so we arrested them.

Another thing we would do-- there were-- it seems that, eh, some of the French boys were ardent Nazis, and they served in the German army, the Wehrmacht. And so some of them happened to be in-- in-- uh-- oh, excuse me, I'm-- I'm jumping the gun. Tom [? Eddingtion's ?] unit was in Clémery, France. Uh, anyhow, so we rounded up a few of these French boys who had been in the German army, and we arrested them.

And, uh, one day, I remember, it was a little hairy. I remember I was w-- w-- in the Jeep with another man, and we arrested this-- this young boy. And he was about 6' 2" and built like a-- a-- a strong man, a real strong man. And we searched him, and we thought we had everything. Then I happened to look down at his boots, and he had a long knife there. Well, of course, that was taken away from him immediately.

Well, anyhow, in France, there wasn't too much to do. But then-- then, uh, shortly after, eh, we, eh, went in-- the army went into Germany, crossing the Rhine. Then we got really busy. Then our job was to arrest eh, eh, certain Nazis. Primarily, in each town, the first person we would arrest would be the Ortsgruppenleiter. That's the head of the-- of the Nazi party in that particular community. And uh, we had advance information who these people were. This had all been prepared.

Of course, m-- most of the men in my outfit had had, uh, training in intelligence. G2, they called it here. I had none, I just had the language. I had no background, but I-- I was learning pretty fast. And, eh, we, um-- eh, we would arrest them, and then we-- we-- we would ha-- there were other people who were influential, uh, in the Nazi party and so forth. And I remember, um, one-- one man we arrested, he happened to-- uh, he was the Ortsgruppenleiter in his town in Germany, and he happened to own a restaurant and liquor store.

Well, the man I was with, um, and my buddy-- we were-- always worked in buddy-- with buddy system-- John Vance. He loved to drink a little bit. So he says-- Syd, he says, uh, let's take a couple of bottles before the GI's get hold of this. So we-- we-- we-- I--I didn't care. So we took a few bottles, and then um, we learned a few days later, [INAUDIBLE] the GI's just ransacked the whole place, you know? Anyhow, one of-- one of the bottles that-- that, uh-- that we-- we took was [? champ wine, ?] a sparkling bur-- burgundy.

And John was drinking like a fish what we had. Then finally, g-- it got to the last bottle. I said, John, I don't want you to touch that bottle. I says, when the war is over, you and I are gonna empty it. That's when we're going to celebrate. Of course, that--that's exactly what we did it. It was a struggle, but we did it.

Anyhow-- and a-- along the way there, little c-- certain things that happened. Uh, I could remember, um, one, for instance, um, in Ludwigshafen I was with John Vance-- incidentally, this John Vance-- brother of Cyrus Vance-- you know, he was the-- in-- in the-- in the Carter regime. And I have his photograph here, along with me. Yeah, that's-- that's John here, and that's myself.
JOANNE RUDOF: And hold up. And where was that photograph taken?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: This is in Kempten, Germany, in Bavaria, in Bavaria. This was after the war, by the way.
JOANNE RUDOF: Mm-hm.

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: But anyhow, we were walking down the street in Ludwigshafen, and the-- the town had just been taken that-- that morning by our division. And we were just walking along the sidewalk. And I happened to look down at one place, and this-- this-- engraved in the cement on the sidewalk was a huge Jewish star-- Magen David. I says now, what the heck is this? And I stared at it, uh, looking. Then I felt somebody staring at me. I looked up.

There was this elderly woman with tears in her eyes. Well, anyhow, the way it developed, she was married to a Catholic. She was Jewish, but she was under house arrest for the duration of the war. She couldn't leave the house whatsoever. Well, she invited me into her house. And as we came in, this elderly woman, she says-- she beckoned to me to go into her bedroom. I went into the bedroom, and she looked around to make sure nobody was looking, you know.

And then she opened a drawer of a dresser. And there were things like aprons and blouses. They all had the Jewish star on them there. And then she looked around very carefully. She was afraid. And she pulled out a siddur, a Hebrew prayer book. And she told me she had managed to hide it all during the war and so forth. And then finally, I told her I had to leave, so we went back into the kitchen. And she had baked mandelbrot. And she gave me the mandelbrot, and I left. I was very, very moved by that incident.
FRANCES COHEN: Who had her under house arrest?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Eh, the--the-- the government. Pardon?
FRANCES COHEN: The government--
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: The government--
FRANCES COHEN: --the Germans?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: --oh yeah, that-- that was the police, the Gestapo.
FRANCES COHEN: Had it-- I see.
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Had her under house arrest. She was lucky she wasn't taken to a camp.
FRANCES COHEN: Right.
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: But because she was married to a Catholic, apparently, [INAUDIBLE].
FRANCES COHEN: They spared her.
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: --they-- they punished her by not-- by house arrest, not having her leave the house at all during the war.
JOANNE RUDOF: Now at this point, you are within Germany?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Yes.
JOANNE RUDOF: What did the word concentration camp mean to you?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Nothing. I had heard about it, but I had no I-- I had very little idea. I know that Jews were interned there, but I didn't know, uh, how they were treated, actually. I'd heard they weren't treated well. But, eh, eventually, you know, when I saw what happened, it was a complete shock. I-- I-- I-- I did-- I didn't know too much about it.

First place, s--s-- some of-- some of my colleagues that had had training in the G2 intelligence school, they had a little idea. But I think most of us didn't. We-- we didn't. And, um, then-- so another incident at the same town, at Ludwigshafen-- one of the things you're supposed to do is check communications between the cities. And I found out that the, eh, telephones were still working between Ludwigshafen and the next city across the river. I forgot the name of it there.

Well, uh, we decided that we had to put a stop to this. Because they could call there and tell us what armaments we had and so forth. So I went to the telephone, eh, company building, and I got hold of the manager there. And I told him to disconnect everything there. So he says, "Ich kann nicht, ich weiß nicht." He says, I don't know how to do it. He says he can't do it.

I says, I'm sorry, you will do it, I says. Then I pulled out my .45, and I says, I'm going to shoot up the whole works here, I says, if you don't do it. So before he p-- he-- he dismantled everything, he-- he did get in a word to somebody across the way. "Ich rede hier was -- ich -- bin gezwungen." I am talking-- I'm being forced to. I-- I says, "Nichts -- nicht sagen, nicht sagen." Anyhow, he took care of that.

Well, it--it so happens that there was a-- a-- a member of the Associated Press traveling with our outfit, and he heard about it. So he wrote me up. But I didn't know what-- what appeared, but my-- my wife did cut out the article-- I have it somewhere at home-- about that incident.
JOANNE RUDOF: So you were right at the front line?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Yes. Yes, that's right, yeah.
JOANNE RUDOF: And were you--

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: As a matter of fact, I did get, among other thing, the combat infantry badge, and-- but I--I didn't actually fire at it. We were-- we were attacked, we were shelled, oh yes. Uh, in-- in France, particularly, there was-- [INAUDIBLE] if I can go back to that-- where I'm-- well, that-- that was a very peculiar thing. I was in a Jeep with another man in-- in France. And four GI's were going on past to Paris, and they were half drunk-- they crashed into us.

Well, the man who was driving was all right. He was a heavy man and he held a steering wheel. And I was thrown out of the Jeep. I landed on my head and my helmet came off. It wasn't strapped under my chin. And I still had a scar where I landed. And, eh, I-- I know my glasses were broken. And when I picked myself up, I could see blood all over my face.

Well, I-- I said to myself, oh my god, what an awful place to die. I says, I want to go home. I want to die at home, at least. Then my next thought was, gee, maybe they'll send me back to Paris to the hospital or something like that, you know? No such luck. So they-- so-- so-- so the medic said, go back to where you're staying.

We were staying in a little house. And at night, we would sleep in the cellar, because the Germans were shelling us. And they-- and they say, and keep your warm. Oh, I had torn ligaments besides. And he said, stay warm. Well, there was a little stove there on the first floor. So I sat next to the stove, it's nice and warm, while the other guys went downstairs. Well, no sooner than I fall asleep, and b-- brother, those shells start coming. And I never dove so fast in all my life down-- down to the cellar there. Well, I--I recovered from that.

Now to get back to Germany, and a couple other things happened on the way. Oh, I remember, for instance, uh, going to Weimar. That's-- that's a picture of the Jewish cemetery that was desecrated there, I remember.
JOANNE RUDOF: And is that you?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: That's myself, yeah, yeah.
JOANNE RUDOF: Now when you were in Weimar, did you know that there were camps in that area?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: We didn't know.
JOANNE RUDOF: No?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: No. Were there [INAUDIBLE] at this point? I don't know. I should imagine there were. There were hundreds of them all over, but we didn't know about that. No, we weren't too much involved with the camps, actually. We were arresting Nazis and so forth. And, um, then-- let's see, the-- oth-- other-- other incidents that-- that occurred. Uh, oh yeah. And-- and then-- a--a-- at some time, I may go ahead of myself times--
JOANNE RUDOF: That's all right.
FRANCES COHEN: It's all right.

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: --and then go back. I [INAUDIBLE] it's-- when it comes to my memory. Right after the war, we were encamped in Germany, Bavaria. And we were arresting people, and I heard about this man who had bragged that he was the "Ich bin der älteste Antisemit" in-- in Kempten. I'm-- I'm the oldest anti-Semite in Kempten. He was bragging about it to his friends. Well, I went to his--his house and arrested him, and I found some-- a letter, some things that he had written which, I don't have, unfortunately, in which he bragged about his anti-Semitic activities there and so forth. Well, they wouldn't let me keep the letter, because they needed-- when they arrested him and tried him, they had to use that as evidence.

Anyhow, he happened to be a tailor by profession. I had also heard of a Jewish man who had just been liberated from a camp who was also a tailor living in Kempten. And he came back, and he had no equipment, no machine or anything to start his business again. Well, I liberated the sewing machine from the Nazi and gave it to this guy. And, um, there was-- there was no-- no questions asked.

Um, then, let's see. There-- let's see now, these pictures may help a little bit. Yeah, now they go back to Nuremberg. This is a photograph of the, um-- the--the tremendous destruction by our airplanes, our bombers, in Nuremberg. That shows part of it, uh, destroyed. And then this is also Nuremberg. This was a huge stadium where they had, uh, festivals where they honored the old German guards and goddesses, Thor and Woden and all those people. They also had the Nazi festivals.
FRANCES COHEN: So you would go in as each city was liberated?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Yes.
FRANCES COHEN: I see.

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: We would go in, yeah. We had a list, um, of-- of the-- the party functionaries, the Nazi party. We write up arrest reports. Excuse me. And then we would send them back with a vehicle to what we called the corps. Not-- we were in the 9th corps. That was a--a higher up unit over a division. And then from there, they did what-- they tried them or sentenced them or whatever, you know? We interrogated them.

And, um, um, of course, most of them [INAUDIBLE] when we talk to them, they said the things they did "Ich war gezwungen," I was forced to do it. I didn't want to do it. And uh, my great-- great uncle knew a man who was Jewish once or things like that, you know? So th-- then, um-- and finally-- well, not finally-- then came our-- our-- a big catch, Ernst Kaltenbrunner

Well, I was assigned that time to work with Robert Matteson, who had a lot of training in intelligence and-- and history of-- of the German c-- of the Nazi party and so forth. He had a tremendous background. Unfortunately, he just died two weeks ago. And, um, he, um-- I was assigned to work with him as an interpreter, and also to, uh-- not only as an interpreter, but to make arrest reports and arrest people and so forth.

And, um, inci-- incidentally, I was more proficient in French than German. But talking to so many German people, after a while, I became fairly fluent in German too. And, uh, so we-- we were going to go to Altaussee, which is in Austria. That's in the s-- what they c-- the area called the Salzkammergut. It's the foot of the Austrian alps. Very pretty town, a very pretty town. Uh, we set up our headquarters, our office.

We know we're going to be there a while in what was formerly the office of the Nazi party in that town. And we-- we started doing some research. Now Ernst Kaltenbrunner was-- he succeeded, um, uh, Heydrich, the Hangman of Europe. Heydrich in 1943, uh, was, uh, in-- in charge of the, uh, eh, Reichssicherheitsamt. That's the uh, eh-- the, uh, security. And he-- he-- he was r-- ruthless and notorious. He went through several countries where he would take care of-- of exterminating Jews, eh, eh, rounding them up, and he was in charge of that.

And he was assassinated by two English-trained Czechs. Well, eh, he lived after th-- he was shot, he lived for a few days. But when he died-- you probably remember-- that's when Lidice occurred. Eh, in revenge for what they did to-- to him, they massacred a tremendous number of Jews in Lidice. Well, Kaltenbrunner-- Ernst Kaltenbrunner was-- took his place.

Now Ernst Kaltenbrunner eventually became the head of security and intelligence-- intelligence both military and foreign intelligence-- and-- and the Gestapo. He became the head. He was a brute of a man, over 6 foot 2. He had a scar on his face. Supposedly, they said it was a scar-- a dueling scar he got when he went to Heidelberg University, we don't know.

Well, we-- we didn't know where he was. But we-- we knew that he had a mistress who was living in Altaussee. Um, her name was, um, Gisela. [INAUDIBLE] I have it right here. Well, [INAUDIBLE] no, yeah, Gisela von Westpark. That was his mistress. His wife helped us. She was an informant. She lived nearby, and we talked to her about, um, his whereabouts, and she gave us a few leads on who might know.

Then after a number of leads, we did find out that he was hiding in the mountains with a Major Scheidler, his adjutant, his aide. Well, it seems that Scheidler's wife was living in-- in the same house as Kaltenbrunner's mistress, and was right across from the hotel where we were staying there. And, um, we-- we c--we couldn't get any information from them. Of course, they-- they tried to pump us, find out what we were doing, and where we w-- where-- were we looking for th-- their men and so forth. We got to be very friendly.

As a matter of fact, they-- they catered to us. They even i-- invite us to dinner once. They had weiner schnitzel. It was excellent. Well, they b--brought out some rare wine too. And-- well, I suppose, I-- Ebensee. I should have come to , I should have -- But let me finish this, then I'll go to . Well--
FRANCES COHEN: Excuse me.
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: --then we decided on a plan of action. These two men w-- were up in the mountains there.
JOANNE RUDOF: About when was this, Mr. Bruskin?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Yes, this was-- yes, this was around the middle of May 1945.
JOANNE RUDOF: Mm-hm.

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: So the plan was that Bob Matteson would dress up in a n-- in-- in Austrian, um, hunter's clothes, lederhosen and the hat with a feather and all that, and so forth. And he would go up, and he would be accompanied by a platoon of about 15 or 20 soldiers-- armed soldiers-- in case there were any problems there. But my job was to keep the household where the women were, and the children and the servants, under house arrest all night long.

So what I did, I call them all into the kitchen. And I took out my .45, put it on the table. And I said, "Niemand wird verlassen hier." Nobody's going to leave this house here at all. Uh, oth-- otherwise, I'm going to shoot you, just like that. Right away, they started asking me questions, what was going on and so forth. And-- I-- I had a feeling they knew, but I-- I says, I'm not going to tell you what's going on.

Well, we, uh-- and the next morning, um, all of a sudden, we hear a little h-- bustling and hustle outside. We go out, and there's Bob with two civilians and the soldiers. Everybody was very weary. It was cold. There snow and ice on the mountains there. They were tired, they hadn't slept, and they were v-- very-- they were really exhausted.

We still didn't know whether these two men were, um, the people we were looking for. But all of a sudden, uh, Mrs. Scheidler rushed off the porch to her husband and embraced him. Well, right away, we knew that we had that guy. And then before long, we knew he had them both.

Well, then while Bob was on the phone making arrangements for high security to come in to pick him up and take him back uh, to the-- the corps headquarters, uh, his mistress-- Kaltenbrunner's mistress-- requested that she'd like to speak to him before they took him away. Well, we looked-- Bob and I looked at each other whether we should or not, and finally said, all right, but I'm to be with them, not to leave them alone. So we went to our office in an adjoining room.

The two of them sat at a table. And I sat between them. Uh, I didn't want any hanky-panky, anybody trying to liberate him or slipping him a-- a-- a gun or anything like that, you know. Well, they didn't say too much to each other. He was very silent, very depressed. I think he foresaw what was going to happen to him. Well, he w-- he was sent back. And, uh, eventually, of course, he was one of the Nuremberg, uh, criminals. He was tried.

And at one point, after they were sentenced to death-- he was one that was sentenced to death, a-- a-- alo-- along with Goring, and, uh, eh-- well, Hess was in prison, but they had a whole bunch of them. He had a stroke, an apoplectic stroke. But the doctor says, oh no, this guy isn't cheating the gallows. So the doctors revived him. They made sure that he lived so that he-- he--he would be hanged.
JOANNE RUDOF: Did you have any, uh, conversation or interrogate him in any way?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: I didn't, no. As a matter of fact, even Bob had very little. Once we knew who he was, we left it to the higher ups. He wouldn't talk. But we know from-- afterward, you know, I did a lot of checking up on what his [INAUDIBLE] was. One of the things he had planned to do, uh-- for instance, he was put in charge of, uh, forming the redoubt area in Austria.

The redoubt area is where, um, uh, Himmler had the idea of establishing an area there where there would have fortifications, where they would have factories there making munitions, and their last stand. And-- and he was in charge of-- of f-- eh, um, eh, the program to build this place up. He also had an idea at one point that perhaps he could get in touch with John Foster Dulles and some of the American people and make a deal whereby he could get a number of SS soldiers he collaborated with the American army to attack the Russians.
JOANNE RUDOF: How did you learn this?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Afterward-- well, Bo-- Bob Matteson made a career out of Kaltenbrunner. When he got out of the army, for years and years-- he took seven trips to Austria and Germany. He interrogated the families there, the children and so forth. And he, uh-- and-- and--and he read all kinds of books and so forth, interviewed people. That was his life.

W-- and-- and he-- he had a very understanding wife. His wife went with him too. Jane went with him wherever he went. I remember he v-- he--he lived in Minnesota. He-- he visited me here in New Haven. And for several days, we talked and talked, and we argued about certain incidents, what-- what happened. We differed on a few things, because-- but we-- we straightened everything out.

And um, then-- let's see, oh, yeah-- Kaltenbrunner-- he ch-- he-- he, um-- he didn't cheat the gallows. And Bob stayed on during the trials too. The trials weren't unt-- until the following year, I believe, 1946. And he didn't go to the actual execution, but uh, he, uh-- he did hear that when-- some-- some of the men, when they stepped to the gallows, they repented. But when Kaltenbrunner got up and they asked if he had a statement to make, he says, no, heil Hitler, that's it. He was just as strong a Nazi as ever. He went up very strong. Well, he was hanged [INAUDIBLE].

Now to get back to something which I should have had chronologically earlier, O-- on our way, Bob picked me up at Kempten, Bavaria, and we were going to go down to Aussee. On our way, we had heard that there was a concentration camp in , which was not far from Altaussee, so we-- we drove there. Well, we got there-- there were-- Bob wrote a-- a-- a book I have at home, a sort of a--a pamphlet. He claims that we broke the lock to get in there. I--I--I s-- I say definitely. I-- I say that we were among the first troops there. I remember going in through the gate, and there were few soldiers there, very few.
JOANNE RUDOF: Do you remember the gate?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Yes.
FRANCES COHEN: You mean American soldiers there?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: May-- May 8th, 19-- May 7th or 8th, 1945. Yeah. Beg your pardon?
FRANCES COHEN: So American soldiers were already there?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: They were there, yeah, but they had come in the same day that we did, we learned later. Bob thinks that w-- w-- we broke the lock, but I don't remember that at all, but we went in.
JOANNE RUDOF: And you were not attached to any unit? It was just the two of you on your way?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: That's right, on our way. That's right, yeah. We got into . I didn't know exactly what to expect. And then I start to see the sights, you know? Men 60 pounds, you know, skin and bones. And I took this picture of one of them. It might have been May 6-- let's see, May 6th, 7th, or 8th. You-- you may have some records about that that collaborate, because--
JOANNE RUDOF: May 6th.
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: May what?
JOANNE RUDOF: May 6th.
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: 6th? Well, that's what I wrote here.
JOANNE RUDOF: Mm-hm.
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: On May 6th, that's the day I took to be right.
JOANNE RUDOF: Mm-hm.

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: That's when I to-- took the picture. That's a picture. Well, this is typical of what I saw. Then we toured one of the lagers where they were, you know? They were sleeping on shelves, and bugs infested, scratching themselves, th-- thin and everything else, you know?

And then we decided we were going to go to the crematorium. Well, we, um-- we went to the crematorium. And first, we saw one room, probably the size of this room here, piled with naked corpses one on top of the other all the way up to the ceiling. And that-- that got me right away. I-- I-- I had-- I had no idea that it would be this bad. And I-- I was just at a loss for words.

Oh, before that-- one thing, though-- we did go through one of the lagers where-- I-- I was talking to some of the inmates there. I was talking mostly in German, some I would talk to in Yiddish. And, um, I just couldn't understand why they were there. And I-- I made the mistake of-- of asking one man, why are you here? And he got insulted.

He was very angry with me for even asking. I knew they were Jewish, but still, it seems to me that th-- th-- they must have committed a crime besides being Jewish, you know? But anyhow, then we went in-- after the looking-- viewing the corpses, we went into the-- the crematorium. There were two ovens there.
JOANNE RUDOF: How did you know about the crematorium even being there?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Well, we knew-- well, oh, th-- th-- well, uh, I don't recall exactly. But it was probably one of the other GI's told us about it while we were there. That's probably what it was. There was a crematorium. Well, we went into the crematorium, and there were two ovens there. There was a sign over one of the ovens. This one.
JOANNE RUDOF: And that's a photocopy of the actual sign?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: That's a photocopy of the actual. The actual sign, I donated to the, um, eh, Holocaust Museum in Washington. As a matter of fact, when I was there in last fall, they, um-- they had a replica of-- of a crematorium-- the ovens of one of the camps-- might have been Dachau-- and there was no sign. So I wrote to, uh, Jack Nowakowski. He's the man in charge of the exhibits, and the, uh, memorabilia there.

And I suggested that he take that sign and put it over the ovens there. I haven't heard from him. Uh, but, uh, I-- my-- my-- friend, um, George Havas, who I'll tell you about later-- he--he goes there frequently. He lives just outside of Washington. I told him next time he's there to look at it.
FRANCES COHEN: Can you translate for us?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Yes, I'll translate it, yes. Uh, a translation says, "not ugly worms must in the future be nourished by my body. The clean flame should first eat me up or devour me. I always love the warmth and the light, therefore, burn my body and don't bury me."
JOANNE RUDOF: And you just took that off the wall?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: I took it off. Actually, I couldn't reach it. There was a man there-- he was an inmate with the, eh, striped uniform. But he was not skinny like these guys. He was what-- found out what they call a kapo. A kapo is a-- a person who is an inmate, but he's a privileged character. He has, eh, certain duties and certain powers over the other people. He wasn't-- they weren't very well liked by most of the inmates there.

This guy was pretty husky, you know? And so I--I told him to get a ladder and take the sign down, which he did. Then I didn't like his attitude, either. He says, eh, all right, I'll give it to yous, because I think I have another one someplace else. I don't know what he was proud of or what. Maybe he-- unless he figured I was going to give him a pack of cigarettes or something, I don't know. Well, I-- it was on heavy cardboard, and I--I managed to get her at home without breaking it, you know. And, um-- now l--let's see, that-- that was Eb-- .
JOANNE RUDOF: Now then--
FRANCES COHEN: Had the Germans all left the camp?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Yes, oh yes. They had all left. We-- in-- in-- in the, um-- in the-- oh, important. Before we went to the camp, we knew we were going to find something bad there. So when we arrested the Ortsgruppenleiter, we made him accompany us there to see what was going on. Of course, he insisted-- even though was only a mile or two from his-- the town-- that he didn't know the-- of its existence.

Well, we took him there. And we were walking around, and showing, and looking at a few things there. And all of a sudden, he disappeared. He ran away from us. We couldn't find him. We-- wh-- but did learn the next day, he committed suicide.

Then we heard of two guards who had been arrested by the, um, anti-Nazi group, and they were sitting in a prison. Uh, eh, they were held there waiting for the Americans to come and pick them up. And there-- one-- one of them was a-- was a real brute. Well, we went there-- I remember it was toward dusk-- and, um, we-- we decided that we would arrest him, but we'd wait till the morning-- uh, the light wasn't very good there-- so to write up the arrest report. Well, when we went there the next morning, he had committed suicide too.
And then-- or then-- then we went back to Altaussee.
JOANNE RUDOF: Now did you talk about what you saw there with the other GI's?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Y--yes, we did, yeah. We-- we had-- we-- well, we discussed it amongst ourselves. Eventually, some of them had maybe-- well, none of them had been to concentration camps immediately upon liberation, like we were. They'd seen them much later. And, um-- and, um-- well, we--we did talk to them, yes.

But it changed my whole outlook on everything. I-- I had never, um, had much of a Jewish upbringing. I n-- we never belonged to a synagogue, I didn't have a bar mitzvah, and so forth. But that changed completely. No, no, I we-- I went back to my roots after seeing, particularly the-- the the camp, and, uh-- and the women w-- in Ludwigshafen and so forth.

And right away, I-- I felt differently. And Bob Matteson, who was a-- a devout Protestant-- you know, he-- he felt the same way as I did too, you know? And, uh-- and the stuff that he's written there, he--he mentions all that there too. Uh, and, um--
JOANNE RUDOF: So you were just in for that one day?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: One day, yeah. Because there were other, um, troops coming in to take care of de-lousing seeing everybody, and-- and feeding them and so forth, you know? And I remember that some of the inmates came up-- give me some food, give me some food. Uh, you guys took care of us, you liberated us, but where's the food?

Well, we learned other things later, for instance, that there-- there was a big, eh, eh, counterfeiting group there. They-- some of the inmates were making counterfeit British m-- eh, money they used there. And we found out that the-- the--the few men who were involved in that, th--they had there-- the Germans-- the-- the-- the German guards had orders to shoot them before they evacuated the camp themselves. But it seems that they never got to do it. Although we did hear stories that some of the, um-- the German guards were-- were manhandled and killed by the inmates. They were bitter.
JOANNE RUDOF: But you had no way to verify these stories? These were just things that other people told?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Well-- well, I wish I'd brought that book with me. No, these are, um-- well, things, of course, as far as-- things that I actually saw, you know, and people say that-- that-- there no, eh, Holocaust. But I-- when I saw bodies piled like that. And-- and-- and then-- then-- I saw the-- the-- crematorium and so forth, you know? There's-- there's no question about it.
FRANCES COHEN: So they were making counterfeit money for the Germans?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: For the Germans, that's right, yes, yeah. There-- one of-- [INAUDIBLE] their plans was they were going to f-- counterfeit, eh, eh, English money. They were somehow going to flood England with it to-- to lower their-- the value of their currency. That was one of their plans. And um, um, let's see. --
JOANNE RUDOF: Did you communicate with your family back in New Haven about what you had seen in Ebensee?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Not until I-- not until later when I came home. First place, things, eh-- things were, um-- we knew it was-- our V-mail was being censored and so forth. I-- I couldn't do it. But when I got home, I--I told. I-- I showed my wife all the pictures, and I told her all about it and so forth. And, um, I had to be discreet about things.

Like I remember when we were in France, we were-- we were at-- at Fontainebleau, 50 miles from Paris. And, um, I hope they don't put me in jail for this, but I went AWOL with another guy. We went to Paris. I'd always wanted to go to Paris. And I said to this man I was with, B-- Bob Holmes-- I says, you know, Bob, uh, we may not come back alive. I'd like to see Paris before I die. So we-- we--we went to Paris. And when I came back, I wrote to my wife and I says, I just visited the city that I've always wanted to visit.
[CHUCKLING]

And-- and she knew exactly what it was. So anyhow, getting back to, uh, um-- well, of course, my reaction-- let's go into this a little more, into Ebensee-- it was shock, at first, unbelieving. I couldn't believe that anything like this could happen, and-- and it was disbelief. And then, of course, it-- it was anger, you know. And then after that, I had no mercy on any-- anybody we arrested. It-- it just carried over into that too.

And e--eve-- even in years later, when-- whenever I-- I ran into any, eh, personal incidents of anti-Semitism, I'd-- I'd bring that up there, like, eh, I'd say, gee, I thought that the war was over, and I thought that we killed Hitler. But I see guys like you are still around. I just lost my temper.

Anyhow, um, I remember c-- coming back, a-- another thing, just to digress for a moment. When I came back, I decided that I was going to become a Jew boy again. I didn't know how to start. And then I got a letter from [INAUDIBLE] Lodge B'nai B'rith inviting me to a breakfast. And any group that approached me at that point, they were-- they were going to get me. I signed up right away. Because I figure this way, I could identify myself as Jewish.

And, um, then-- let's see, all right, th-- then b-- back at Altaussee, uh-- oh, there were other people that we arrested there. There was one g-- gentleman. Eh, let's see, Joyce, I believe his name was. He was an Englishman. And he, together with Lord Haw-Haw-- Lord Haw-Haw-- had started the program under Goebbels of broadcasting, eh, Nazi propaganda in English to Eng-- yeah, Baillie-Stewart, his name was. Earlier, Baillie-Stewart-- w-- we arrested him. Bob wrote out the arrest report form.

He-- he was from British nobility. And he-- from 1933 to 1938, he was a spy in England for the Nazis. Um, he-- he was eh-- he was checking the armaments, the, um, a-- armored vehicles and the tanks and so forth. Because e-- e-- eventually, you know, eh, eh, the na-- the-- the-- the Germans knew they were going to be in war. And he was in that, and then he w-- he was-- he was captured in England. And he was sentenced to the Tower of London.

You know, in England, when a ma-- person of nobility has to go to prison, they put him in the Tower of London. And with influence, they got him out in 1938. So then he be-- went to Germany, became a German citizen. And he, um-- then he was with-- of course, eventually, he was arrested, so I don't know what happened to him after that.

Uh, then there were, uh, other, uh people we arrested there. Oh yes, I personally arrested the Frau Eigruber. Eh, she-- her-- you see, Austria was divided into four districts called a gau. And her husband, uh, was the Gauleiter of this particular district, Eigruber. And she, uh-- I remember wh-- when I arrested her, I-- I interviewed her at length for personal interest, and also for the arrest report.

And, um, um, I asked her one question, was had she ever met Hitler? Very proudly, she says, oh yes, he was in my house once. She was thrilled. She was proud of it. And then another time, out of her-- out of the clear blue sky, she looked at me and she says, oh, my grandmother once was treated by a Jewish doctor. I don't know, now she should try to impress me, you know? And, um, that was one-- one of them.

Let's see. There were, um-- [INAUDIBLE] now. Oh yeah there was-- there was the-- an ambassador from Latvia who came in on his own to be arrested. Because he didn't want the Russians to get hold of him. He figured that we would treat him better. Well, we arrested him, and I don't know what happened to him later either.

Um, then when-- when I was-- then I was told I was to go home. Bob stayed on there. Um, he volunteered to stay on. And he arrested a few other people later, uh, some of the people who had been informants, telling us about different Nazi-- they themselves were ca-- guilty of collaborating with the Nazis. He ar-- he arrested some of them. One of them was Prince van Hohenlohe, who had-- who-- who was-- spoke pretty good English. He had been married to, um, an American woman, an heiress, very wealthy woman.

And, um, then, um-- let's see, where were we? Let me just look at my notes here. Oh yeah, then-- then there's this guy, um, George Havas. It seems that on the 40th anniversary of the liber-- the liberation of Ebensee, Bob happened to be in that area. on one of his seven trips there. And they had there-- apparently, there is a-- a monument or a memorial or something there. And they had a ceremony, um, celebrating the liberation 40 years.

And while he was there, he happened to run into this man, George Havas. That's not his picture, although George showed me his picture once, which is very similar to this one. And the two of them became quite friendly. And then at-- Bob-- oh, then George wanted to know if-- if-- who he was with when he went to Ebensee. So Bob told him about me. And then, eh, George contacted me.

He had a little trouble reaching me. Uh, he didn't-- and-- and Bob-- and one-- la-- later in years, Bob got hold my address, but at that point, he didn't have it. So he, uh, contacted the Yale alumni office for my address. They wouldn't give it to him, it's confidential. So what he did, though, he sent a letter to me care of them, and then they sent it to me.

So after that, we-- we talked on the phone. And we-- th--this was maybe 10 years ago or so. We talked on the phone, and, uh, we, uh, wrote to each other and so forth, you know? And he was an inmate there. And um, then when-- when-- and of course, he-- he-- he collaborated a lot of things that I had seen too, you know? And he-- he-- he knew very well. But he didn't recognize this picture, though, of that person.
JOANNE RUDOF: He was a prisoner in Ebensee?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: He was a prisoner, yeah, an inmate.
FRANCES COHEN: But you hadn't met him when you were there?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: No, no, no, not at all, no. He-- he was Jewish. He was-- his family came from Czechoslovakia. And-- and he-- he, uh-- he, uh-- Czechoslovakia was occupied by the Hungarians for a number of years, so we learned the Hungarian language pretty well. And he still does interpreting for the Holocaust museum now, it-- for Hungarian-- in-- Hungarian there. And he's-- he's a very pessimistic sort of [INAUDIBLE]. He never got over his experience there. He's-- he's done a lot of different things.
JOANNE RUDOF: What is his name?

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Havas, H-A-V-A-S. And I invited him to come here sometime. I spoke to one of you about-- and I told him about what I was going to do, and about Ebensee, and how they have tapes of other people in Ebensee. He'd love to see them sometime. As a matter of fact, I just got a letter from him. He says, he-- if they want to to interview me, he'd be glad to.
JOANNE RUDOF: Mm-hm.
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: And then, um, let's see. See what I have here. Let's see.

SYDNEY BRUSKIN: Oh, are we, really?
JOANNE RUDOF: --regroup a little bit, OK?
SYDNEY BRUSKIN: All right. Oh, a couple other things. Just--

1. Sidney had married Shirley Levine (1917-1990) and they had a daughter, Phyllis, in 1943. U.S. draft policies in World War II were such that, with a wife and child, Sidney was not immediately drafted. The Selective Training and Service Act of 1940, also known as the Burke–Wadsworth Act, enacted September 16, 1940, “was the first peacetime conscription in United States history. This Selective Service Act required that men who had reached their 21st birthday but had not yet reached their 36th birthday register with local draft boards. Later, when the U.S. entered World War II, all men from their 18th birthday until the day before their 45th birthday were made subject to military service, and all men from their 18th birthday until the day before their 65th birthday were required to register.… By the early summer of 1941, President Franklin D. Roosevelt asked the U.S. Congress to extend the term of duty for the draftees beyond twelve months to a total of thirty months, plus any additional time that he could deem necessary for national security…. After the United States entered World War II, amendments to the Selective Training and Service Act on December 20, 1941, made all men between the ages of 20 and 44 liable for military service, and required all men between the ages of 18 and 64 to register.… From October 1940 until March 1947, when the wartime Selective Training and Service Act expired after extensions by Congress, over 10,000,000 men were inducted.” More broadly, the U.S. federal government has turned to the draft six times in history (American Revolutionary War, the Civil War, World Wars I and II, and the Korean and Vietnam conflicts). Conscription came to an end only in 1973 when the United States Armed Forces became all-voluntary. 2. A brief word on the facilities mentioned by Bruskin: “Armory Court,” one observer noted, “is a building of power. Located at the north end of Orange Street, right before East Rock Park, this ‘medieval castle’ stands out imposingly from the residential surroundings.
